newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: Lithuanian right faces test of currency policy.
newsitem.headline: Lithuanian right faces test of currency policy.

text.p: Lithuania's right-wing began preparations for a coalition government on Tuesday after victory in a first round of elections but seemed set for possible wrangling over control of the litas currency, analysts said.
The right-wing Homeland Union of Vytautas Landsbergis came first in the election, displacing the former Communists of the Lithuanian Democratic Labour Party.
The Homeland Union has said it favours more privatisation and wants to put the large state-owned companies such as Lithuanian Airlines up for sale.
One of its key policies is scrapping the currency board, under which the litas is set at a rate of four to one dollar, and giving back the central bank all its powers.
The IMF says the currency board is vital for litas stability and it is linked to Lithuania's agreements with the Fund.
The IMF and western diplomats believe the system is the only one to keep inflation falling, and trust in the litas.
The Homeland Union insists the currency board has led to an overvalued currency, which is strangling exports.
But it says that ending the system does not mean the currency will be devalued, as some fear.

"Nobody is talking about devaluation...but we feel that it is better for Lithuania to go to a system of a strong national bank," Andrius Kubilius, chairman of the Homeland Union's parliamentary faction, told Reuters.
Under the currency board, the central bank keeps enough hard currency in its vaults to match the money in circulation. But it cannot intervene in the market or change interest rates.
"I would not have thought the economy was strong enough to allow a free floating currency," one diplomat told Reuters.
